docs.lead_paragraph: WHILE most people try to lose excess pounds for esthetic reasons, many also expect to accrue the health benefits long associated with leanness. But recent studies reveal some surprising facts about the effects of weight loss on risks of developing diabetes, heart disease and cancer. For example, a six-year study showed for the first time that weight loss can prevent the most common type of diabetes, type II or noninsulin-dependent diabetes. But the study also showed that people at risk of developing diabetes need only lose about half their excess weight to protect their health. The study, directed by Dr. Jose Caro of Thomas Jefferson Medical College in Philadelphia, involved 113 "morbidly obese" patients whose ability to process blood sugar was impaired.
